meta.content: Fast Pulling of n-Type Si Ingots for Enhanced Si Solar Cell Production
meta.name: dc.title

meta.content: Electronic Materials Letters 2018 14:4
meta.name: dc.source

meta.content: 2018 The Korean Institute of Metals and Materials
meta.name: dc.copyright

meta.content: Reducing the manufacturing costs of silicon substrates is an important issue in the silicon-based solar cell industry. In this study, we developed a high-throughput ingot growth method by accelerating the pulling speed in the Czochralski process. By controlling the heat flow of the ingot growth chamber and at the solid-liquid interfaces, the pulling speed of an ingot could be increased by ~ 15% compared to the conventional method, while retaining high quality. The wafer obtained at a high pulling speed showed an enhanced minority carrier lifetime compared with conventional wafers, due to the vacancy passivation effect, and also demonstrated comparable bulk resistivity and impurities. The results in this work are expected to open a new way to enhance the productivity of Si wafers used for Si solar cells, and therefore, to reduce the overall manufacturing cost.

meta.content: Fast Pulling of n-Type Si Ingots for Enhanced Si Solar Cell Production - Electronic Materials Letters

Abstract Reducing the manufacturing costs of silicon substrates is an important issue in the silicon-based solar cell industry. In this study, we developed a high-throughput ingot growth method by accelerating the pulling speed in the Czochralski process. By controlling the heat flow of the ingot growth chamber and at the solid-liquid interfaces, the pulling speed of an ingot could be increased by ~ 15% compared to the conventional method, while retaining high quality. The wafer obtained at a high pulling speed showed an enhanced minority carrier lifetime compared with conventional wafers, due to the vacancy passivation effect, and also demonstrated comparable bulk resistivity and impurities. The results in this work are expected to open a new way to enhance the productivity of Si wafers used for Si solar cells, and therefore, to reduce the overall manufacturing cost. Graphical Abstract

div.p: Advertisement

div.div: Fast Pulling of n-Type Si Ingots for Enhanced Si Solar Cell Production

header.h1: Fast Pulling of n-Type Si Ingots for Enhanced Si Solar Cell Production
header.p:
Electronic Materials Letters
volume
14
,
pages
461–466 (
2018
)
Cite this article

li.p:
337
Accesses

2
Citations

div.p: Reducing the manufacturing costs of silicon substrates is an important issue in the silicon-based solar cell industry. In this study, we developed a high-throughput ingot growth method by accelerating the pulling speed in the Czochralski process. By controlling the heat flow of the ingot growth chamber and at the solid-liquid interfaces, the pulling speed of an ingot could be increased by ~ 15% compared to the conventional method, while retaining high quality. The wafer obtained at a high pulling speed showed an enhanced minority carrier lifetime compared with conventional wafers, due to the vacancy passivation effect, and also demonstrated comparable bulk resistivity and impurities. The results in this work are expected to open a new way to enhance the productivity of Si wafers used for Si solar cells, and therefore, to reduce the overall manufacturing cost.

The worldwide consumption of electricity is increasing annually as standards of living improve, and there is greater use of electrical equipment, vehicles and devices [
1
]. Among the various energy sources used to generate electricity [
2
,
3
], solar energy has attracted attention as one of the most promising renewable energy sources, because of its sustainability and eco-friendliness. However, the high cost of electricity produced by solar energy remains a big hurdle to its further application.

In the solar cell industry, multi-crystalline solar cells (MSC) and single-crystalline solar cells (SSC) account for 50 and 30% of the market share, respectively [
4
,
5
]. The MSC and SSC have been competing with each other to enhance cell efficiency and reduce manufacturing costs using state-of-the-art silicon solar cell technologies. For example, a recently-developed passivated emitter rear contact (PERC) structure has been reported to achieve 21.25 and 22.13% efficiency with MSC and SSC, respectively [
6
,
7
].

One way to minimize the time required for the body growth process is to increase the ingot pulling speed. This can be increased by maximizing the temperature gradient of the melt along the ingot growing direction in the vicinity of the solid-liquid interface, which is enabled by adjusting the rotation speed of both the crucible and crystal [
9
,
10
]. Inserting heat shields between the free surface of the melt and the outer surface of the ingot prevents heat loss caused by radiation from the melt to the ingot [
11
].

Moreover, as the crystal ingots grow from liquidus silicon to solidus silicon, latent heat is generated at the interface between solid and liquid. The latent heat flows out to the crystal surface through heat conduction, and subsequently the heat flow outs from the crystal surface through both convective and radiative heat transfer. Introducing cooling water jackets (CWJ) around the growing ingots promotes the release of the latent heat along with the solidification rate, and thus, the overall pulling speed increases [
12
,
13
,
14
].

In this study, we developed a high-throughput ingot growth method by accelerating the pulling speed of the ingots during the Cz process. For comparison, we produced single crystalline n-type Si ingots at a normal pulling speed (NormalPS) and at a 15% higher pulling speed (FastPS). FastPS was enabled by controlling the heat flow in the growth chamber and at the solid-liquid interfaces. The ingots made with two different pulling speeds were evaluated in terms of resistivity, minority carrier life time (MCLT), oxygen concentration, and carbon concentration. In addition, n-type solar cells were fabricated using wafers diced from these ingots, and evaluated. The wafers and solar cells obtained from the FastPS ingots exhibited properties equivalent to the ones obtained from NormalPS ingots with enhanced MCLT, which can lead to the enhanced production of Si solar cells with reduced manufacturing cost.

Commercial polysilicon and quartz crucibles were utilized for the modified Cz process with fast pulling. Two polycrystalline Si batches of 106 kg were charged with phosphorous (n-type dopant) in a 20 inch quartz crucible and were moved into single crystal growing chambers, one with and one without a cooling water jacket (CWJ), as illustrated in Fig.
1
. The chambers were pumped down to vacuum, and then electrical power was supplied to a graphite heater to melt the poly Si contained in the quartz crucible. Following the complete melting of the poly Si, a single crystal seed with (100) orientation was dipped into the Si melt. The single crystal seed was pulled upward and the neck process with a diameter of 4–5 mm was executed to remove slips from the seed. It was then continued to the shoulder process to enlarge the diameter up to 170 mm, which was the target dimeter. Following the shoulder process, the body growing process was performed to produce a uniform single crystal ingot. The crucible was rotated counter-clockwise at a speed of 5–8 rpm, while the crystal was rotated in the opposite direction at 10–12 rpm during the body growing process. The Ar flux was 30–50 lpm, and the pressure in each chamber was maintained at 10–30 Torr during the body growing process.
Schematic diagram of a Si ingot growing chamber with cooling water jackets used for the modified Cz method

After the body growth finished, the ingots were cropped into cylindrical bricks for the MCLT measurement, and a few slugs were examined to measure oxygen and carbon contents. The MCLT values were measured at the center of the cropped surfaces of the cylindrical bricks (BCT300, Sinton). Resistivity was measured by the four-probe method (CMT-SR5000, AIT) following thermal annealing for doping. The interstitial oxygen (Oi) and substitutional carbon (Cs) contents were measured at the center of the polished slugs by FT-IR spectroscopy (QS2200, Nanometrics).

To fabricate n-type SSC using these ingots, wafers with a thickness of 500 μm were prepared from three different positions, from the top, middle, and body of the ingots. Then, ion implantation was performed to form a boron-doped emitter on the front side of the wafers and a phosphorus-doped BSF layer on the back side. Prior to forming metal contacts, standard RCA cleaning was performed to remove organic and metallic residues on the surface. After the RCA cleaning, a Ti/Ag back contact and Al/Ag front contact grid were formed by electron-beam evaporation. Solar cell performance was evaluated at AM 1.5G illumination using a solar simulator (K3000, McScience).

Figure
1
depicts the Cz growth chamber with cooling water jacket. The silicon melt is contained in a quartz crucible with a minimum of contamination. A graphite heater provides heat to the poly silicon and silicon melt inside the quartz crucible. The chamber is equipped with several components used for heat control. Insulators prevent heat loss from the chamber. Heat shields made of both graphite and insulators block heat radiation from the melt surface to the ingot surface. The CWJ takes heat away from the ingot surfaces during growth.

Figure
2
a shows a comparison of the pulling speed of NormalPS and FastPS as a function of the solidification fraction ratio (SFR), which corresponds to the weight ratio of the solidified Si to the initial liquid Si during the body growing process. The FastPS pulling speed is about 15% faster than the NormalPS along the entire SFR. This difference is attributed to the improved cooling of FastPS by the CWJ, in contrast to the NormalPS without a CWJ.

Comparison of
a
the relative pulling speed and
b
the relative power to target values during the body growing process as a function of the solidification fraction ratio for NormalPS and FastPS

In general, the Cz method is divided into four stages; the neck process, shoulder process, body growing process, and tail process. The purpose of neck process is to eliminate dislocations through vertical growth while maintaining a small diameter. During the body growing process the main part of the Si ingot is obtained via vertical growth at the desired target diameter. The shoulder process bridges the neck and body growing process, during which the ingot grows horizontally. Therefore, the growth mode has to be changed from vertical to horizontal (neck → shoulder) and subsequently horizontal to vertical (shoulder → body growing). The two sharp valleys around 0.015 in the SFR in Fig.
2
a result from an overshoot in the pulling speed following the over-shoulder process, which needs a relatively higher pulling speed for the second growth mode change.

The relative powers used for NormalPS and FastPS are compared in Fig.
2
b, as a function of SFR. The FastPS consumes 7% more power along the entire SFR, compared to NormalPS, which is necessary to compensate the heat loss caused by the CWJ used for the FastPS. The required power falls below 0.2 in SFR for both the NormalPS and FastPS. This is likely due to the additional heat of fusion generated at the solid-liquid interfaces and the suppressed loss of heat radiation resulting from the decreased free surface area of the melt.

As presented in Fig.
3
a, the MCLT measured at the center of the ingots decreases gradually for both NormalPS and FastPS with increasing SFR. Segregated and accumulated metals in the remaining Si melt induce the reduction of MCLT. It is known that a high pulling speed can improve MCLT due to vacancy passivation [
5
], and FastPS shows a much higher MCLT in the low SFR regime (< 0.4) than NormalPS, due to this vacancy passivation. The large difference in the MCLT becomes smaller as the solidification proceeds, and the MCLT of both the NormalPS and FastPS is identical at an SFR of 0.7 or higher, due to metal impurity-dominant domains [
5
]. This is attributed to the segregation phenomena of the solid and liquid silicon. As SFR increases, metal atoms are accumulated in the remaining silicon melt. As a result, the metal concentration increases very sharply at the end of body and this suppresses the vacancy passivation effect.

Comparison of
a
the minority carrier life time measured at the center of the ingots and
b
the resistivity profiles adjusted with experimental values as a function of the solidification fraction ratio for NormalPS and FastPS

The theoretical resistivity, calculated using Scheil’s equation and the Shimura equation, was established in relation to dopant concentration and the resistivity of Si [
15
,
16
], and was found to decrease with increasing SFR in both NormalPS and FastPS due to the accumulation of segregated phosphorus. As plotted in Fig.
3
b, the two resistivity curves exhibit no noticeable difference when they are adjusted to match with the experimentally measured values of 1.07 O·cm (NormalPS) and 1.24 O·cm (FastPS). This is attributed to the same amount of dopant added to the stack of polysilicon in quartz crucible for both NormalPS and FastPS. In addition, as summarized in Table
1
, both the NormalPS and FastPS show similar concentrations of interstitial oxygen (O
i
) and substitutional carbon (C
s
), which are below 18 ppm and below 1 ppm, respectively, regardless of the sample position in the ingot. The differences are within the allowance of mass production and the properties of ingots have no dependency on the pulling rate.

figcaption.b: Table 1 The concentration of Oi and Cs in the NormalPS ingot and FastPS ingot, depending on the sampling positions. The unit is ppm

div.p:
As the resistivity and oxygen/carbon impurity concentration profiles indicate, the two ingots produced by NormalPS and FastPS are apparently similar to each other. To further evaluate the wafer qualities depending on the pulling speed of the ingots, we measured the V
oc
of the Si solar cells fabricated from the respective wafers. V
oc
is one of the most appropriate measures for this purpose because it depends mainly on the bulk properties of the Si wafers and is less affected by other factors, such as electrical contacts and optical losses [
17
]. The Si wafers were sampled at the seed, middle, and tail positions from both the NormalPS and FastPS ingots. Subsequently, Si coupons of 2 cm × 2 cm were randomly selected from each position: one, two, and three coupons from the center, halfway, and edge position, respectively, as shown in Fig.
4
a.

The influence of pulling speed and wafer position on the Voc of Si solar cell.
a
The Si coupons used for solar cell evaluation were randomly selected at each position: center, halfway, and edge area.
b
A schematic illustration of the Si solar cell structure.
c
–
d
The Voc of Si solar cells fabricated using the
c
FastPS ingot, and
d
NormalPS ingot

A simple solar cell structure was used, as described in Fig.
4
b. It consisted of a
p
-type emitter, n-type base substrate, n+ BSF (back surface field) layer, and a Ag electrode without any passivation layer. As shown in Fig.
4
c, d, the V
oc
of the solar cells made from the FastPS and NormalPS ingots had similar profiles regardless of the positions. The highest V
oc
s of 581 mV (FastPS) and 574 mV (NormalPS) were achieved from the center position of the wafer, obtained from the middle part of the ingots, while the solar cells from the seed and tail positions exhibited lower V
oc
with a larger deviation. This implies that the high concentration of O
i
and C
s
deteriorates wafer qualities, and thus solar cell efficiency. In addition, within a wafer sampled from the middle part, V
oc
decreased by about 10 mV as it was tested outward from the center to the edge position. Although the reason for this is unclear, it is probably related to non-uniform doping profiles and impurities originating from the crucible. Further investigation is necessary to clarify the reduction of the V
oc
depending on the horizontal position within a wafer.

In conclusion, we developed a modified Cz process for Si ingot production based on the fast pulling of ingots, which was accomplished by controlling the heat input into the chamber and by improving cooling at the solid-liquid interfaces. Using this method, we successfully demonstrated that 15% higher productivity could be achieved while retaining comparable wafer qualities; the ingots produced by the fast pulling method had similar resistivity and impurity profiles to the ones made by normal pulling, and had even higher minority carrier life times, due to the vacancy passivation effect. Solar cells fabricated using the wafers obtained in the middle of the ingots showed the highest Voc, irrespective of the pulling speed. The results in this work are expected to open a new way to enhance the productivity of Si wafers used for Si solar cells, and therefore, to reduce the overall manufacturing cost.
